entry.title: Re: Follow-Up Material Not Considered In MRP Run
entry.content:
Hello All,

We have found out the root cause of the issue, it was happening because of the low-level code for materials. As per SAP standard, MRP plans the materials from lower low-level code then towards the higher low-level code. In our-case discontinued material has higher low-level code than that of follow-up material; due to which MRP was planning the follow-up material first and then planning the discontinued material, whereas MRP should plan the discontinued material first and then follow-up material. So, we have corrected our low-level code through MM02 and now MRP planning the materials correctly.

entry.title: Extending SBPA Processes with APIs and Using Them in Integrated Product Development
entry.content:
Introduction

In the first blog post, we built and deployed a functional workflow in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) and connected it to Integrated Product Development (IPD). Now, it’s time to take the next step: extending your process with API integrations.

In this article, we will explore how to set up and use APIs within SBPA processes to enrich your workflows with collaboration data and advanced functionality from IPD. You will learn how to:

  • Add and configure destinations
  • Set up and manage Actions in SBPA
  • Include and execute API calls directly within your process

Our specific goal in this post is to retrieve the Collaboration Name via an API call and make it visible inside a form within your workflow. By the end of this post, you’ll know how to connect SBPA to IPD Collaboration APIs and enrich your workflow with live collaboration data.

Prerequisite: You need a functional IPD workflow in SBPA. If you haven’t created one yet, you can follow my step-by-step guide to build a process in SBPA and integrate it into IPD.

 

Guide

Step 1: Register the EDP_Collaboration destination in SBPA

  1. From the SAP Build (SBPA) Lobby, open Control Tower.
  2. Under Backend Configuration, click Destinations.

Step 2: Select the EPD_Collaboration destination

  1. To add a destination, click the Add button.
  2. Choose the EPD_Collaboration destination from the list.
  3. Click Next to proceed to Associate Environments.

Step 3: Associate the destination with environments

  1. In the Associate Environments step, choose how the destination should be available:
    • All Environments: makes the destination usable in every SBPA environment.
    • Specific Environments: select only the environments where this destination should be active.
  2. Click Add Destination to save.

Step 4: Create an Actions project

  1. In the SBPA Lobby, go to Connectors → Actions.
  2. Click Create (top-right).

Step 5: Import the IPD Collaboration API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub

  1. In your Actions project, click Choose an API Source and select SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  2. In the search bar, type Collaboration and select Collaboration (ODATA) under SAP Integrated Product Development (IPD).
  3. Import the API into your Actions project.

Step 6: Create the Action Project

  1. After selecting the Collaboration API, you will be prompted to create an Action project.
  2. The Project Name and Description are prefilled with default values. You can keep them or adjust as needed.
  3. Click Create to finalize the Action project setup.

Step 7: Add Available API Actions

  1. A list of API actions from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub will appear.
  2. Select the APIs you want to use for your collaboration scenario (for this guide: Retrieve a collaboration for the specified collaboration ID).
  3. Confirm with Add.
  4. All chosen API actions will now be available in your Action Project.

Tip: If you want to add an API later, open the Available Actions window using the Add button next to Actions.

Step 8: Add missing "From" header for IPD APIs

For many IPD APIs, an additional From header is required. This header is not automatically included and must be configured manually.

  1. Open Add under the Parameters section.
  2. Configure the parameter as follows:
    • Key: From
    • Mandatory: Yes
    • Parameter: header
    • Type: string
  3. Add the parameter.

To check whether an API requires the From header, refer to the SAP API Business Hub – EPD Collaboration API.

Step 9: Save, Release and Publish the Action Project

  1. Click Save.
  2. Click Release.
  3. Click Publish.

Step 10: Move back into the process

After releasing and publishing the Action Project, return to your process model to continue the setup.

  1. Open your project in SAP Build Process Automation.
  2. Switch the project from Deployed back to Editable mode by selecting the dropdown and choosing Editable.
    • This allows you to make changes to the process again.
  3. In the project overview, click on your process (e.g., IPD Process) to reopen it in the process editor.

Step 11: Add the CollaborationID and TechnicalUser as custom variables

  1. Under Process Details, configure Custom Variables.
  2. Add CollaborationID and technicalUser as custom variables.
    • You can either set the technicalUser directly as an initial variable or define it later in a Script Task.

Step 12: Extract the Collaboration ID from the Business Key

  1. Add a Script Task to your process.
  2. In the script editor, insert the following JavaScript logic:
// get Business Key
var businessKey = $.context.startEvent.businessKey;

// delete "Collaboration"
var collaborationId = businessKey.replace("Collaboration", "");

// Write in Context
$.context.custom.collaborationid = collaborationId;
$.context.custom.technicalUser = "your@mail.com"; // enter the technical User Mail

Step 13: Add Collaboration Actions

  1. After the Script Task, add a new element and select Action.
  2. This connects the Collaboration API (configured earlier) directly to your process.
  3. You can either reuse an existing action from your library or add a new one by selecting Browse All Actions.
  4. In the Action Library, search for and select the Collaboration API you want to use (In this guide the API: Retrieves a collaboration for the specified collaboration ID).

Step 14: Configure Destination Variable

  1. Choose a Name for the step.
  2. Under Destination Variable, create or select the variable that points to your Collaboration destination.
  3. When deploying the workflow, set this destination variable to EPD_Collaboration.

Step 15: Configure API Inputs

  1. In the workflow action settings, navigate to the Inputs tab.
  2. For the field From, select the variable technicalUser.
  3. For the field ID, select the variable CollaborationID.

This maps your process data to the API request. All responses from the API call are available as variables, which can be mapped and used in the input fields.

Step 16: Add result from API to your Form

  1. Open the form.
  2. Click Open Editor.
  3. Add a Text Field and name it Collaboration Name.
  4. Save the form.
  5. Return to the Process and open the Input tab of the form.
  6. Add the Collaboration Name into the field.

Step 17: Save, Release, and Deploy the Project

  1. Save your project after adding the API steps.
  2. Release the project to make it ready for deployment.
  3. During deployment, set the Destination Variable to the EPD_Collaboration destination.

Step 18: Start the Workflow in SAP IPD

  1. Open the My Collaborations app in SAP IPD.
  2. Select a collaboration where the workflow is already linked to the collaboration type (see how to do that: SBPA Guide)
  3. Add the workflow to the collaboration.

Note: This requires that you have completed all configuration steps from the SBPA guide, including setting up the Business Key, defining the Subject, and configuring the Workflow Properties and other prerequisites. Since the process was already configured, deploying it in SBPA only creates a new version of the workflow. When you start the workflow in IPD, the newly deployed version will be executed. 

Step 20: Check the updated form in My Inbox

  1. Open the My Inbox app in SAP IPD.
  2. Select the task created by your workflow.
  3. In the form, locate the text field Collaboration Name.
  4. The field now displays the Collaboration Name that was returned by the API.

Optional: Monitor the Workflow

  1. Use the Monitor Workflow app to track execution details.
  2. In the monitoring view, verify that the API call is executed successfully and inspect the request and response data if needed.

Conclusion

Great work! You have successfully extended your workflow in SAP Build Process Automation by integrating APIs and connected it with Integrated Product Development. With the Collaboration API in place, your process can now dynamically retrieve and display collaboration data, such as the Collaboration Name, directly inside your forms.

Beyond this example, you can use many other APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to enrich your workflows with additional business data, collaboration features, or system integrations. This demonstrates how SBPA can go beyond simple workflow automation and become a powerful integration layer for IPD.

Alexandra Rong,
Business Process Consultant for SAP IPD,
alexandra.rong@sap.com

entry.title: Does SAPIS have the capability to connect with PostgreSQL DB hosted on Bastion server via SSH tunnel
entry.content:
Dear Integration Experts,

We are working on a requirement to fetch data from a PostgreSQL database that is hosted on the Bastion server. The DB Admin team is requesting us to connect via SSH Tunneling. They have also shared a PEM file to be used during the connection.

In SAP IS, we do not see any configuration to enable SSH tunneling or use the PEM File in the DB connection. I have searched the entire SAP community and did not find any options to enable connection to DB via SSH tunneling.

Has anyone come across such a requirement? Any workarounds or approaches that can be explored to enable this connectivity?

Edit (1): Just wanted to add that we were able to connect to the DB via DBeaver (by configuring SSH Tunnel and PEM File import).

Regards,

Prajeet

entry.title: SAPUI5 Timeline Component - App Hangs with Busy Indicator Randomly.
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

I'm developing a custom SAPUI5 application and I'm using the <suite:Timeline> component to display approval history in a cost approval workflow. The data is retrieved using a V2 OData service from the /ProcessLogs endpoint.

📌Problem Description:

The timeline works most of the time, but intermittently, the app gets stuck on the busy indicator (oView.setBusy(true)), and the form becomes completely unresponsive. There is no error in the console, and the issue is not consistently reproducible — it appears randomly.

This issue affects usability as the user cannot continue without refreshing the entire application.

🔧Functional Flow

  1. On opening the form, I call the function onFetchTimelinessData.

  2. It reads from the /ProcessLogs entity using OData V2.

  3. On success, I bind the results to the Timeline control.

  4. The Timeline renders approval status history for that request.

🧩 Code Snippet

VIEW CODE:-
<suite:Timeline
id="detailsTimelinedataADPD"
axisOrientation="Vertical"
showTimeFilter="false"
height="500px"
sort="false"
showItemFilter="false"
enableScroll="true"
growingThreshold="40"
content="{timelinesslogdata>/results}">
<suite:TimelineItem
dateTime="{
parts: ['timelinesslogdata>createdAt', 'timelinesslogdata>remarks'],
formatter: '.formatDateTimeWithRemarks'
}"
title="{
parts: [
'timelinesslogdata>role',
'timelinesslogdata>userName',
'timelinesslogdata>userEmail',
'timelinesslogdata>status'
],
formatter: '.formatTimelineTitle'
}"
text="{timelinesslogdata>remarks}"
userPicture="{timelinesslogdata>userPicture}"
icon="sap-icon://employee-approvals"
status="{timelinesslogdata>status}" />
</suite:Timeline>


CONTROLLER CODE: -

onFetchTimelinessData: function () {
var reqid = this._reqIDData;
var oView = this.getView();
var that = this;
var oModelV2 = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("approvalservicev2");

oView.setBusy(true); // Busy starts

oModelV2.read("/ProcessLogs", {
filters: [new sap.ui.model.Filter("reqID", sap.ui.model.FilterOperator.EQ, reqid)],
sorters: [new sap.ui.model.Sorter("receivedDt", false)],
success: function (oData) {
oView.setBusy(false); // Busy ends

if (oData && oData.results) {
var aProcessedData = oData.results.map(function (oLog) {
return {
createdAt: oLog.createdAt,
role: oLog.stage ? "[" + oLog.stage + "]" : "[N/A]",
userName: oLog.userName || "Unknown User",
userEmail: oLog.userEmail || "N/A",
remarks: oLog.stage === "Seek Clarification" ? oLog.clarification : oLog.remarks,
status: statusMap[oLog.status?.toUpperCase()] || ""
};
});

var oJSONModel = new sap.ui.model.json.JSONModel({ results: aProcessedData });
oView.setModel(oJSONModel, "timelinesslogdata");
}
},
error: function (oError) {
oView.setBusy(false);
sap.m.MessageToast.show("Failed to load process log data.");
}
});
}

 

 




Despite my efforts, I'm still looking for an effective solution. If anyone has experienced something similar or has expertise in this area, your advice would be greatly valued.

Thank you in advance for your support and time!

entry.title: Re: SAP DM - Plant Mapping/Conversion: Integration of dif...
entry.content:
I have gone through the SAP DM plant mapping documentation you linked and your description, and the behaviour you’re seeing usually means one of the two mapping “directions” or one of the prerequisite integration settings is missing or mismatched.

In SAP DM, plant mapping is handled in SAP Cloud Integration (SCI) via the Plant Value Mapping artifact. For each ERP system/plant you integrate, you must maintain two separate entries:

SAP’s example in the guide shows both entries for each plant

When mapping is not working, it could be due to the following reasons:

  • You would have maintained only one direction like if you have only entered DEVSYSTEM:1000 → 1000D and QASSYSTEM:1000 → 1000Q once each, you may have only covered the outbound mapping. You also need the inbound mapping entries using the ERP destination name (the one defined in SCI pointing to your ERP system), not the logical system name.
  • The left‑hand key must exactly match the logical system name (for outbound) or the ERP destination name (for inbound) plus a colon and the ERP plant ID. Even a case difference or extra space will cause the mapping to be skipped.
  • In the “Initial Parameters” artifact in SCI, ENABLE_PLANT_CONVERSION must be set to TRUE and the iFlow redeployed.
  • DM plant would not be active for S/4 integration. In DM’s Manage Business Settings, the DM plant (e.g. 1000D) must have the correct ERP destination assigned and S/4HANA integration mode enabled.
  • If you’re testing with LOIWCS (ERP → DM), only the outbound mapping entry is used. If that works but inbound fails later, it’s the second mapping that’s missing.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Mind Your Step (Walking and Hiking)
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm Moshe Naveh from the SAP Community team. Today, I'm excited to kick off a new SAP Community virtual journey: a blogging series focused on the passions and hobbies of our community members. In this series, community members will share about themselves, their hobbies, how they got started, how they incorporate them into their routine, and how you can learn them as well. This series will be enriched with fun stories, inspiring anecdotes, images, videos, and more. Each community member will tag another member to join the series via their mutual interest. For now we've lined up community members with the following hobbies: painting, Mindfulness, Yoga, skydiving, running, and more! 

I want to start the series by sharing a hobby that has been my passion for a long time: long walks and hiking. It all started when I did my first step, around the age of eighteen months😉. However, when I was a teenager I started taking long walks. I used to love to walk on the beach just before the sun switched turns with the moon. There was a sculpture of a bird that always inspired and reminded me that I'm free to go wherever I want. 

The title of this blog post, "Mind Your Step," reflects my state of mind when I walk. I try to be mindful of every step I make. Each step not only brings you closer to the finish line but also can take you deeper into your own thoughts and relaxation. 

Now, I would like to share with you some pictures from my most significant hikes and walks that really are a part of who I'm today:

Bolivian Jungle

Around 2004, I went on a long hike in the jungles of Bolivia (a couple of hours drive from La Paz). It was an amazing experience where I met new people and formed meaningful connections. For a couple of days we walked through jungles, slept in remote areas, and relied on each other's trust to navigate the unknown. 

Isla Grande, Brazil

Another memorable hike from around 2004 was my visit to Isla Grande which is an island not far away from Rio De Janeiro. After settling down in the camping ground, I met two cool people which later became my friends. Shortly afterwards we decided to do a hike of 40 km to cross the island from bottom to top. I was the man of the day as I saved everyone by bringing "just in case" food in my bag. My friends thought we would find food in the middle of the jungle:). They returned a favor by searching for me when I got lost in the jungle (they found me😉). We finished our hike when we reached the tip of the island. The traditional dish of rice and beans was so tasty. For sure it was refreshing after eating Tuna, cookies and Goose liver Pate for five days.  The timing of arrival to the finish line was perfect as we got there just in time for the weekly ferry to the main village.

Luxembourg's Little Switzerland

Three years ago, I did the longest walk I've ever done in one day (30 Km). It was in the magnificent area of Luxembourg called "Little Switzerland." The trail resembled Switzerland's mountains and had stunning views. The focus wasn't just the amazing nature and yummy blackberries but also my state of mind during the hike. It was with certainty one of my most special days in my entire life:

That's how I look when I finish a 30 KM hike 

And it was such an amazing view:

I'm standing on a bridge over a swamp

 

and here are the tasty blackberries:

 

25 km walk

During my recent holiday, I decided to dedicate one day for a long walk. I walked on the beach or not far away from it for 7-8 hours. I tried to walk always in the shade of buildings as it was very hot. I constantly bought food, snacks, and drinks (which seems to be my favorite part of the walk😉). 

This is how I looked after finishing the journey:

Moshe standing next to a tree after finishing 25 KM by foot

 

Running!

Recently, I started practicing for a race so I started running. Although I was already in shape from walking 15–20 km daily, running gave me a whole new feeling of energy:

After my first 12 KM run!

  and I really enjoy stopping in my favorite street and eating all sorts of fruits that are available for everyone:

Grapes

Recently I started to be interested in races. Here's a picture from a race that was raising funds for children with cancer:                                                                   

Moshe in a running race

Subscribe to this post as I'll add in the comments pictures from the upcoming race, after I complete it:).

Why did I start walking and running?

I really enjoy walking as it calms me down, excite me and keeps me in shape. It's a kind of meditation for me. Running is also very relaxing but at a different pace than walking. I hope I'll keep doing both for a long time, while doing it right to maintain a healthy body. Also starting a day with a morning run keeps you energized at least until lunch:).

Passing the baton:

Now, I'd like to hand it over to Achim ( @act45 ). Achim has been a community member for many years and I'm sure many of you know him. I was fortunate to meet Achim in person in SAP TechEd. Achim will share his amazing experiences and journey around being a yoga teacher and a Mindfulness enthusiastic. As I practice Mindfulness during my runs and walks, I think it's a great continuation for our blogging series.

Do you do long walks or hike? Share the pictures and stories behind them in the comments section. Feel free to share other hobbies you have! 

If you're interested in joining the series, please reach out to me via community@sap.com.

Let's get this journey going! I hope you all enjoy the great posts coming-up!

entry.title: Implementing OIDC Authentication for SuccessFactors API Integration
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

Requirement Overview:
We are working on integrating a front-end application with SuccessFactors. In this scenario, users log in through the front-end application and request their information from SuccessFactors. To enable this, we need to expose the SuccessFactors OData APIs to this application.

SuccessFactors OData APIs support OAuth 2.0 with SAML Assertion. The typical process is:

  1. Request a SAML assertion.

  2. Use the SAML assertion to obtain an access token.

  3. Use the access token to query the APIs.

Currently, for the SAML assertion step, we are using the /oauth/idp API to generate SAML assertions for our exposed APIs. This setup is working, but as per the official documentation (link), this method is considered insecure and has been deprecated, which may affect the APIs we expose to external systems going forward.

Proposed Solution:
We are planning to implement OIDC-based authentication for the APIs exposed from SuccessFactors to external systems.

  • We followed the official guide to configure the Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning services (link) and attempted testing using Postman.

  • During testing (Step 10), we were asked to select the “SAP SuccessFactors” application, but the option only works when “Administration Console” is selected.

Further testing, as per this guide, yielded the following:

  • We successfully called the /oauth2/token API and obtained an ID token from the Identity Authentication service.

  • We made a second API call to obtain an API access token using the ID token from the previous step.

  • However, using this access token, we are unable to access APIs in the SAP SuccessFactors HCM suite. Getting the 401 authentication error while querying SuccessFactors OData APIs:

    Error Response:
    **********************
    {
    "error": {
    "code": "AuthenticationFailed",
    "message": "Authentication service failed to return token.",
    "details": "Failed to authenticated OIDC token"
    }
    }
    ************************

Key Requirements:

  • The official documentation suggests using grant_type=password, which we want to avoid for security reasons.

  • We intend to use grant_type=authorization_code so that users can log in via SSO through the front-end application, and their session can be used to access the APIs.

  • We would appreciate guidance on setting this up, specifically:

    1. How to configure the authentication flow for users logging in through the front-end application.

    2. How to configure it when an application (rather than users) needs to consume SuccessFactors APIs.

We request your help in setting this up correctly and securely. Leads to documentation/blog posts or any sort of help will be highly appreciated. 

@CarlosRoggan @DeepakGDeshpande 

Regards,
Pavan

entry.title: Re: Error while receiving with multiple batches which is...
entry.content:
In SAP, for split valuation + batch management, each batch is hard‑linked to exactly one valuation type in the batch master (table MCH1). When you post a GR for a purchase order (or inbound delivery), the valuation type is determined once for the PO item either from the PO item itself (if valuation type is fixed there), or from the first batch line you enter in MIGO.

Once the valuation type is set for that PO item in the GR transaction, all subsequent batch splits for that same PO item must have the same valuation type. If you try to enter a second batch with a different valuation type, the system sees it as a mismatch and raises the error. This is standard SAP behaviour — you cannot post multiple valuation types under a single PO item in one goods movement.

To overcome from this, you have few options:

  • In the purchase order, create one line item per valuation type. Each line item will then allow only batches belonging to that valuation type. In MIGO, you’ll post GR for each PO item separately or in one go, but each item will only have batches of its own valuation type.
  • If the PO item is already created without split, you can post GR for the first batch/valuation type. Then post a second GR for the other batch/valuation type. This works but is less clean than having separate PO items.
  • If you regularly receive multiple valuation types for the same material in one delivery, adjust your purchasing process so that the PO reflects that — one item per valuation type.

So the key takeaway here is this is not a config bug and that is how SAP enforces the 1:1 relationship between PO item ↔ valuation type. If you need to receive multiple valuation types, you must split them into separate PO items or separate goods movements.

entry.title: Difference and Relationship Between Job Profile Builder and Employee Central in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Within the SAP SuccessFactors ecosystem, Job Profile Builder (JPB) and Employee Central (EC) play pivotal yet distinct roles. Although they serve different functions, their integration is what enables organizations to manage employee data and talent development as one unified process. Gaining clarity on how these two modules differ, and how they complement each other, is key to unlocking their full value in driving workforce growth and operational efficiency.

 

Relationship and Integration


Despite being separate modules, JPB and EC are tightly interwoven in day-to-day HR operations. Their synchronization ensures consistency across processes, from recruitment to career progression.

  • JPB defines the framework for each role: It outlines job requirements, skills, and expected competencies, creating a standardized structure for positions across the organization. This helps streamline hiring, performance reviews, and career development.
  • EC centralizes employee information: It stores and manages all personal and professional data, such as promotions, transfers, organizational assignments, and historical records. It connects each worker to their specific job role and tracks how those roles evolve over time.
  • How they interact: When an employee takes on a role, EC automatically aligns their personal record with the corresponding profile in JPB. This integration affects not only skills assessments and training assignments but also succession planning and long-term career management.
  • Core to HR digitalization: EC acts as the central repository of workforce data, while JPB provides the talent framework that supports strategic HR planning. Together, they form the backbone of modern, cloud-based HR management.

 

Practical Applications

  1. Recruiting and Onboarding
    Recruiters rely on job profiles designed in JPB to clearly set out expectations in job postings. Once a candidate is hired, their data flows into EC and links automatically to the relevant profile. This connection simplifies onboarding and sets the foundation for growth and performance evaluation.
  2. Performance Management
    During evaluations, managers assess employees against the competencies and responsibilities defined in JPB. Meanwhile, EC records achievements, role changes, and progress, building a complete picture of an employee’s professional journey.
  3. Career and Succession Planning
    JPB highlights the skills and knowledge needed for future leadership roles. In EC, employees can explore career paths, track progress toward next-level positions, and receive learning recommendations that align with their current and target job profiles.

 

Summary


Job Profile Builder (JPB) = Defines the requirements of each role (responsibilities, skills, competencies).

Employee Central (EC) = Holds the information about the employee filling that role (personal data, contracts, history).

By working together, JPB and EC bring structure to both the organization’s needs and the people who meet them. This seamless integration supports a connected HR ecosystem, powering recruitment, development, learning, performance management, and payroll all within one platform.

And here you have a summary table of the differences and complementarities of JPB and EC. 

 

FeatureJob Profile Builder (JPB)Employee Central (EC)
Main PurposeDefine and manage job profiles and their attributes: competencies, skills, responsibilities, families, and roles.Manage employee master data: personal information, contracts, organizational location, hierarchies, payroll.
Data ManagementData related to positions, roles, and organizational descriptions.Data related to people: personal and employment information.
ModularityUsed in Talent modules: Recruiting, Performance, Development, Succession, Learning.Its own module in SuccessFactors (EC), but integrates data for other areas (payroll, compensation, learning).
FocusOrganizational: Structure and content of positions within the company.Individual: Current and historical information for each employee, including change history.

I hope this short post helps shed some light on the fundamental ideas behind two of the most essential elements in SuccessFactors. My goal is to make these core concepts clearer, particularly for those who may be newer to the system or have had only limited hands‑on experience.

entry.title: Re: CAMT.053 no longer interprets the data medium referen...
entry.content:
Hi Rado, @radoslaw_parzentny 

I'm afraid I can't help you 100%. However, if your customer is using SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, I'd strongly recommend you to help them switch to processing rules which can be maintained in the Manage Processing Rules app. Processing rules are the successor feature of the posting rules and we generally recommend to use them instead of the old posting rules. (The posting rules are going to be deprecated at some point in time in the future, so the sooner your customer switches, the better.)

Processing rules contain conditions and actions. If bank statement items fulfil the rule's conditions, then the rule's actions are carried out. 

For example, you could try setting up a processing rule with the right conditions and with the Data Medium Exchange (0040) processing instruction in its actions. That processing instruction is connected to the 019 interpretation algorithm. For more information on processing rules, see also the following help content: 

- Manage Processing Rules - For Bank Statements
- How to Create Processing Rules
- Overview on All Predelivered Processing Instructions

Again: I do not know if that answer helps you for your current problem. But it's definitely something to consider for the future. 🙂 

Best regards,
Anita

entry.title: Re: Migrate partially confirmed production orders
entry.content:
If the client won’t allow you to reverse or close the partially confirmed orders in the source plant, you can’t “move” the live order itself to the new plant.  SAP doesn’t support changing the plant on an existing production order, and you can’t have the same order number active in two plants. What you can do instead is treat this as a cut‑over replication exercise, not a physical migration of the order object.

Accept that the source‑plant orders will remain open and they will continue to hold their confirmations, goods issues, and WIP in Plant A. From a finance and logistics perspective, you’ll need to decide whether they will be completed in Plant A and settled there, or left open for historical reference only.

entry.title: Sales Order: Automatically Derive Functional Area via Revenue Projects
entry.content:
When creating a Sales Order, there are different ways to automatically derive a functional area. However, if functional areas are not maintained in G/L accounts and profit centers are not used with indirect derivation via cost centers, another option is available: Revenue Projects. In their master data, a functional area can be maintained, which is then automatically adopted during sales order creation.
Step-by-Step Guide: Deriving the Functional Area from a Revenue Project

  1. Ensure that no functional area is maintained in the G/L account.
  2. Verify that the Revenue Project has a functional area assigned and that the project status is set to Released.
  3. Create a Sales Order using the corresponding Revenue Project.

     


  4. Generate the invoice from the Sales Order.
  5. Review which functional area was used during posting and identify the object from which it was derived.

As demonstrated, the functional area is successfully derived from the Revenue Project during posting when G/L accounts have no functional areas, profit centers are not used, and the accounts are intentionally kept functional-area free. This approach ensures reliable automatic derivation without requiring any changes to the existing system logic.

entry.title: Re: creating workflow CR to block/unblock employee in SAP...
entry.content:
Hi, note 2570961 states

Business partners which are assigned to one of these role categories cannot be maintained using SAP Master Data Governance for business partners, customers or suppliers.

The usage of such workforce business partners in SAP Master Data Governance is also restricted:

  • In partner function maintenance: Only the ID of the workforce business partners is visible, and navigation to that business partner is not possible.
  • In business partner relationships: Relationships to workforce business partners are not visible and thus can’t be maintained.

So unless I'm very much mistaken, blocking Employees via MDG isn't possible.

Best regards, Ingo

entry.title: Re: COPY Feature in SAP Fiori Element List Report App
entry.content:
I encountered a similar issue when trying to mimic "Copy as" function in SM31/SM30, then I've documented my approach here for future reference.

According to the SAPUI5 documentation, both List Report and Object Page support adding a default "Copy" button.

For a practical example, you can refer to the sample program Navigate to new Enity after copy action by gregorwolf.

 

In my approach, I implemented copy action to perform an INSERT into draft table. Specifically, I first inserted a record into the DraftAdministrativeData table, followed by an insertion into the target entity.

I’ve found that this method is only effective when the entity’s key fields are immutable at the time the draft is created—such as a UUID or an auto-incremented number. In other words, once the copy action has been performed, key fields like company code or customer code cannot be modified within Fiori Elements, since the copy action commits to the database immediately.

entry.title: Re: I want to color the SAC input controls according to t...
entry.content:
Hi @tsuuuu

Yes, you are correct, new analytic apps can no longer be created in SAC and therefore you only have access to the optimised story experience. This means that functionality was only feasible in Analytic Application with scripting+CSS.

Styling for entire input control is possible in stories but it applies globally to the whole control and not to individual items.

  • You can adjust these settings through the styling panel in the story designer. Select the input control widget àchange font, background colour, etc.
  • If story CSS editor is enabled in your tenant proceed to apply global CSS rules for the widget class.

For individual item styling, note that it is still not supported in the optimised story experience. Does not look like SAP has provided scripting hooks or per-option CSS classes.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Що дає курс “Applying Localization as a Self-Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition"
entry.content:
Наполегливо рекомендую курс “Applying Localization as a Self-Service for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition" не тільки технічним консультантам та партнерам, а й усім, хто хоче зрозуміти, які можливості локалізації та побудови стійких рішень є в SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Що для мене було найбільш корисним

  • Чіткі засади локалізації як самообслуговування та робота в керованих середовищах.
  • Налаштування онлайн‑перевірок і податкових кодів для відстроченого податку.
  • Adding Custom Fields (вбудована розширюваність).
  • Configure Custom Pricing (кероване налаштування умов ціноутворення без кастомного коду).
  • Створення структури для обов’язкової звітності через кастомні категорії, визначення фаз звітування, призначення організаційних одиниць і налаштування активностей для ефективної комплаєнс‑звітності
  • Інтеграція із SAP Document and Reporting Compliance для електронних документів і звітності.

Чому варто звернути увагу

  • Типові сценарії розширення локальної версії, що постачається SAP, для покриття специфічних галузевих або регіональних вимог як швидший шлях до відповідності локальним вимогам.

  • Побудова клієнтської локальної версії з використанням доступних інструментів самообслуговування там, де потрібне швидке рішення в межах корпоративних політик і контролів

  • Більше керованості та прозорості змін.
  • Менше кастомного коду й нижчий TCO завдяки керованим розширенням.

Реєструйтесь тут 🔗: https://lnkd.in/eiBgfZJa . 

Завдяки курсу Ви отримаєте не тільки знання, а й підтвердження вашої кваліфікації таким бейджем.

entry.title: Re: abapGit plug-in to import the ABAP Flight Reference S...
entry.content:
Hello @peter_munt4 

Your screenshots show an ADT/abapGit pull into a /DMO/* package in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (ABAP Cloud). The error Change recording must be activated for package /DMO/FLIGHT_REUSE

This happens because in Public Cloud, you cannot create or modify objects in SAP namespaces like /DMO/*or abapGit; therefore, you cannot create that package and can not enable recording on it.

What possible works in S/4HANA Public cloud

Do not use /DMO/*.
Create your own ABAP Cloud package (e.g., ZFLIGHT) via File ▸ New ▸ ABAP Package (Cloud). This creation process automatically sets Record Changes to On.

Pull with a customer prefix.
In abapGit repo settings:

    • Branch: abap-platform-cloud (you already have this).
    • Folder Logic: PREFIX.
    • Prefix: e.g. ZDMO_.
    • Package: your ZFLIGHT.
      This renames /DMO/* repo objects to ZDMO_* and stores them in your change-recordable package.

Open a Cloud transport.
In the Transport Organiser view, ensure you have an ABAP Cloud transport request (task) assigned to your user. If you do not see one, create a changeable package again (step 1) or ask the admin to grant the ABAP Cloud dev role and assign the software component.

Expect a few skips.
Some demo artifacts in the sample may not be released for S/4HANA Public Cloud; abapGit will mark those as not creatable and skip them.

Key constraint

If your goal is to use the SFLIGHT objects in an AMDP class: AMDP is not permitted in ABAP Cloud / S/4HANA Public Cloud. Use ABAP SQL/CDS and released the APIs  instead.

Let me know it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing User Experience in SAP Guided Buying
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my latest blog. 

My name is Angeline Gregory, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the UK.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Guided Buying.

SAP Guided Buying can steer users towards more efficient and compliant buying processes.  It is crucial to integrate advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into your buying processes to enrich the experience.

The below features in SAP Guided Buying make purchasing decisions smoother and smarter and hence improve cost effectiveness and increases compliance.

Catalog Item Recommendation

The item recommendation feature suggests products and services based on users' past purchases.  It collects purchasing history from your organization and uses artificial intelligence to recommend catalog items that might be of interest based on the individual user. Item recommendations display in a carousel at the top of the home page, in the item details page or as alternatives to non-catalog item.

This feature improves productivity by:

  • Encouraging usage of catalog item when creating a non-catalog request​
  • Reducing effort when searching for items​
  • Reducing distractions when browsing
  • Improving user experience ​

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_ITEM_RECOMMENDATIONS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription 
  • At first SAP Guided Buying will show “Popular Items” based on organization’s most frequent purchases.  AI will learn and start showing “Recommended for you” items / services based on users clicks​.

Guided Buying Usage Report

The usage report in Guided Buying gives administrators insight into user searches, purchases, and overall interaction with SAP Guided Buying. SAP Guided Buying generates this report monthly to provides usage details, such as the number of users who signed in, number of users who added items to their cart, total number of items added to carts, and searches that returned no results.  This report helps answer business questions like which catalog areas to expand and the most popular search items.  By leveraging the insights from the Usage Report, organizations can continuously improve user experience based on data.

This feature improves efficiency by:

  • Highlighting opportunities based on user behavior, search patterns​ and search effectiveness analysis​
  • Aids making catalog improvements and helps bring spend under management​
  • Providing evidence- to make quicker design decisions

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_USAGE_REPORTS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • ​This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription
  • SAP Guided Buying generates reports only after at least 100 unique users have cumulatively clicked “Add to cart” more than 1,000 times.  It must first collect and analyze a significant number of searching and purchasing actions 

​By using these features in guided buying systems, organizations can significantly help shape the way users buy goods or services.

Integrating AI and ML into guided buying isn't just about improving technology; it's about strategically enhancing the procurement process better suited to users' needs, while staying compliant and cost effective.

So, whether you are just starting out or looking to refine your procurement processes, consider how AI and ML can make a significant impact on your organization's guided buying system and watch as your bottom line and operational efficiencies improve.

Take the next steps by having a look at our comprehensive one-pager on AI and ML in SAP Guided Buying.

Thank you for reading my blog!!

entry.title: SAP TechEd 2025: Check out the Cloud ERP Track!
entry.content:
SAP TechEd goes Hybrid

Join us in person at SAP TechEd Berlin on November 4-6, 2025 or online at SAP TechEd Virtual on November 4-6, 2025 to connect with SAP experts, broaden your technical expertise and to explore the latest innovations in application development.  

 

  What is in for me in the Cloud ERP Track? 

In the  track “Digital Transformation with Cloud ERP” you will explore how  Cloud ERP supports your digital transformation with solutions for your needs. Whether you’re adopting your first ERP or migrating from an existing one, learn how cloud ERP offers a comprehensive, modular, and extensible solution driven by built-in AI and analytics. 

This track covers a broad range of topics, including transitioning paths to SAP Business Suite with tools, services, and methodologies, extensibility both on-stack and side-by-side on SAP Business Technology Platform, clean core, architecture, AI, and many more.  

Our experts will not only talk about the latest innovations but will also showcase various demos and share best practices with you. You will also have the opportunity to gain hands-on experience.

entry.content:
The dump still happens in ABAP 7.58.

Impossible to use @search.defaultSearchElement: true on a column calculated by CASE ... END (whatever level this column appears in the cascaded CDS views).

Runtime error RAISE_SHORTDUMP, CX_SADL_DUMP_DATABASE_FAILURE:

  1. The program has indicated exception "CX_SADL_DUMP_DATABASE_FAILURE" as the reason for the termination: An unrecoverable error has occurred: See previous in exception chain. The exception is related to the previous exception "CX_SADL_GW_V2_FATAL_REQUEST" that occurred in program "SAPMHTTP", in line 0 of include "???".
  2. The reason for this exception was: Fatal error in SADL OData v2 request processing (mapping provider 'ZSD_OFFCOM') The exception is related to the previous exception "CX_SADL_SQL_EXECUTION" that occurred in program "CL_SADL_SQL_EXECUTOR_EXC_HNDLRCP", in line 2 of include "CL_SADL_SQL_EXECUTOR_EXC_HNDLRCM001".
  3. The reason for this exception was: Execution of a SADL-assembled SQL query failed, see previous exception The exception is related to the previous exception "CX_SY_OPEN_SQL_DB" that occurred in program "CL_SADL_SQL_EXECUTOR==========CP", in line 66 of include "CL_SADL_SQL_EXECUTOR==========CM00A".
  4. The reason for this exception was: The database has returned the SQL code 7. The error message is: feature not supported: CONTAINS predicates on expression CASE WHEN VBAK.SUBMI <> '1' THEN 'A' ELSE 'B' END.

SAP explanation (HANA limitation): 3232246 - feature not supported: CONTAINS predicates on expression "<expression>" - SAP for Me.

Problem also mentioned in this other question but still no solution): Search filed on a calculated field - SAP Community.

entry.title: Re: Group reporting: Unable to Consolidate correctly Equi...
entry.content:
Hello @TULLEYC 

Thanks, Colin, this is very helpful.

Brief response to your two points.

App name-
The app I meant is Manage Ownership Data (tile under Consolidation → Ownership). App IDs differ by tenant and release, so don’t worry if you don’t see F3440.

Manage Consolidation Group Structure - Unit View

How to exclude indirect ownership from the investment-elimination rule so 172100 is not affected twice

Do two things:

Maintain ownership as direct-only in the master data.

In Manage Ownership Data, maintain only the direct links:

  • J0184 → J0196: S0002 Direct Share = 30%
  • J0196 → J0197: S0002 Direct Share = 40%

Do not keep a J0184 → J0197 line at all (neither S0002 nor S0001)

Run Calculate Group Shares and Post Group Shares so the system derives the 12% indirectly for reporting, but there is no direct J0184↔J0197 relationship for rules to trigger.

Restrict the elimination rule for 172100 to direct share only.

In configuration, Define Rules for the Elimination of Investments

Find the rule that removes FS item 172100 (Investments in Subs/JV/Associates) with document type 3A.

Set Share for calculation to Direct Share (S0002).
This ensures the rule doesn't apply to group or indirect shares.

Make sure the rule requires a Partner Consolidation Unit, meaning it only works when there's a direct parent–child link.

For the Equity Method consolidation method, either:

Deactivate/remove any 172100-elimination row or keep it active only for subsidiary or proportionate methods, not for equity method methods.

Practical effect:
J0196↔J0197 (direct) still eliminates 172100 once.
J0184↔J0197 (indirect) won’t trigger because there's no direct link, and the rule only applies Direct Share.

Check your method assignment

For equity-accounted entities, use the provided Equity Method naming/numbers, which vary by content, but fall under the category Equity method.

Avoid using a Parent-Direct Shares method for equity-accounted investees; that method typically applies to full/prop subsidiaries and can unintentionally trigger 172100 elimination.

Carry out the sequence to verify.

Ownership: Calculate Group Shares → Post Group Shares

Consolidation Monitor: 02 Prepare Group Structure Changes: changes should not affect the equity-method units → 30 Consolidation of Investments

Check 172100 on J0197: you should see only one elimination in the direct J0196↔J0197, not two.

SAP Help-Manage Data Ownership

Please let me know how it goes.

With regards

Chuma
